{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Renhō |native_name = {{nobold|{{lang|ja|蓮舫}}}} |native_name_lang = |image = Renho Minshu 20130714.jpg |order = |office = [[Leader of the Opposition (Japan)|Leader of the Opposition]] |monarch = [[Akihito]] |primeminister= [[Shinzō Abe]] |term_start = 1 October 2016 |term_end = 27 July 2017 |predecessor = [[Katsuya Okada]] |successor = [[Seiji Maehara]] |office1 = President of the [[Democratic Party (Japan, 2016)|Democratic Party]] |term_start1 = 1 October 2016 |term_end1 = 27 July 2017 |predecessor1 = [[Katsuya Okada]] |successor1 = [[Seiji Maehara]] |office2 = Member of the [[House of Councillors (Japan)|House of Councillors]] |term_start2 = 11 July 2004 |term_end2 = |predecessor2 = |successor2 = |constituency2 = [[Tokyo's At-large district|Tokyo]] |majority2 = |office3 = Minister of State for Government Revitalization |term_start3 = 8 June 2010 |term_end3 = 27 June 2011 |predecessor3 = [[Yukio Edano]] |successor3 = Yukio Edano |primeminister3= [[Naoto Kan]] |office4 = [[Minister of State for Consumer Affairs and Food Safety]] |term_start4 = 14 January 2011 |term_end4 = 27 June 2011 |predecessor4 = [[Tomiko Okazaki]] |successor4 = [[Goshi Hosono]] |primeminister4= Naoto Kan |office5 = Minister of State for Government Revitalization |term_start5 = 2 September 2011 |term_end5 = 13 January 2012 |predecessor5 = Yukio Edano |successor5 = [[Katsuya Okada]] |primeminister5= [[Yoshihiko Noda]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|11|28|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] |birthname = Hsieh Lien-fang (謝蓮舫) |spouse = Nobuyuki Murata |children = Suiran and Rin (twins) |nationality = [[Japanese people|Japanese]] (1985–present)
[[Taiwanese people|Taiwanese]] (1967–2016) |education = [[Aoyama Gakuin University]]
[[Peking University]] |party = [[Constitutional Democratic Party of Japan|CDP]] |otherparty = [[Democratic Party (Japan, 2016)|DP]] (2016–2017)
[[Democratic Party (Japan, 1998)|DPJ]] (2004–2016, merger) |residence = Tokyo, Japan |website = {{URL|www.renho.jp}} }} {{nihongo|'''Renhō Murata'''|村田 蓮舫|Murata Renhō|extra=born 28 November 1967}}, commonly called just {{Nihongo4|'''Renhō'''|蓮舫}}, is a [[Taiwanese people|Taiwanese]] [[Japanese people|Japanese]] politician and former journalist who is a current member of [[House of Councillors (Japan)|House of Councillors]]. She was the leader of the major Japanese political party, the [[Democratic Party (Japan, 2016)|Democratic Party]]. == Early and personal life== Born '''Hsieh Lien-fang''' ({{cjkv|c=謝蓮舫|p=Xiè Liánfǎng|r=Sha Renhō}}) in [[Tokyo]] to a [[Taiwan]]ese father ({{nihongo4||謝哲信|Xiè Zhéxìn}}) and Japanese mother ({{nihongo4||斉藤圭子|Saitō Keiko}}), she studied at [[Aoyama Gakuin]] in Tokyo from kindergarten through university. She enrolled in the law faculty of [[Aoyama Gakuin University]] and graduated in 1990 with the [[Bachelor of Laws|B.L.]] degree in [[public law|Public Law]]. Born as a citizen of the Republic of China , she did not become a citizen of Japan until 1985 when the [[Japanese nationality law|Nationality Law]] was amended to allow Japanese mothers to pass Japanese nationality to their children.{{cite web| url = http://ukinjapan.fco.gov.uk/en/help-for-british-nationals/living-in-japan/marriage-birth-death/how-register-birth| title = Birth Registration| accessdate = 10 June 2010| publisher = British Embassy in Japan}}{{cite web| url = http://renho.jp/profile| title = Renho Profile| accessdate = 10 June 2010 | publisher = Official Renho Website| language = Japanese}} She was legally a [[Multiple citizenship|dual citizen]] until 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201707190042.html|title=It's official ... opposition leader Renho is 100% Japanese|last=|first=|date=2017-07-19|work=The Asahi Shimbun|access-date=2017-10-10|language=en-us}} She adopted her mother's surname, {{nihongo4||斉藤|Saitō}}, when she acquired Japanese citizenship; to avoid name confusion in her career, she began to go simply by '''Renhō'''. After her debut as a [[Clarion Girl]] in 1988, Renhō appeared on several television and radio programs as a commentator. In 1993, she became a newscaster on [[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] and [[TV Asahi]], covering several historical events including the [[Great Hanshin earthquake]].{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/cabinet/cabinet.html?formed=20100608_01&date=20100608&member=17|title=Renho, Cabinet Profiles, Kan Cabinet (Formed 8 June 2010|publisher=The Japan Times}} She was married in 1993 and studied the [[Chinese language]] at [[Peking University]] from 1995 to 1997. Renhō returned to television in 2000, anchoring and reporting on several TBS programs. She reported from Taiwan during [[Chen Shui-bian]]'s presidential campaign, which brought her to the attention of Taiwanese political leaders.{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2004/08/16/2003198960 |title=Japanese politician with roots in Taiwan latest media darling |work=Taipei Times |date=16 Aug 2004 |page=3 |author=Su, Joy}}
{{cite news |author=Huang Tai-lin |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2004/08/17/2003199064 |title=President wants Ren Hou to be bridge |work=Taipei Times |date=17 Aug 2004 |page=3}} In Taiwan, she is often referred to as '''Lien-fang''', the [[Standard Chinese]] pronunciation of her given name. ==Political career== In July 2004, Renhō was elected to the House of Councillors representing Tokyo as a member of the [[Democratic Party (Japan, 1998)|Democratic Party of Japan]]. Since election, she has been heavily involved in parenting issues and policies. Renhō has criticized Japan's diplomacy with China and its refusal to recognize Taiwan, stating that "Japan is too polite when dealing with China, taking a low profile" and "Taiwan is my father's country. Why isn't Taiwan a country?" Since taking office, she has traveled to Taiwan several times on official and unofficial business, garnering extensive public and media attention, and has become close to senior members of the [[Democratic Progressive Party]]. === DPJ government (2009-12) === After the DPJ assumed the reins of government in September 2009, she received much public attention for her stern stance and direct questions to bureaucrats during special [[finance|fiscal]] screening committees of the {{Interlanguage link multi|Government Revitalization Unit|ja|3=行政刷新会議}} established under [[Yukio Hatoyama]].[http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20100605p2g00m0fp031000c.html PROFILE: Renho spotlighted in waste-cutting debate] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611063914/http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20100605p2g00m0fp031000c.html |date=2010-06-11 }}, [[Mainichi]], 5 June 2010 In June 2010, then Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] appointed her as Minister for Administrative Reforms.{{cite news|last=Pesek|first=William|title=Ex-Model Gives Economic Change New Meaning|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-09/former-model-gives-meaning-to-economic-change-commentary-by-william-pesek.html|accessdate=12 January 2013|newspaper=Bloomberg L.P.|date=9 June 2010}} Upon taking the post, Renhō stated that she would be giving particular attention to eliminating waste in the 21 government account.Hongo, Jun, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100609x2.html Renho beats drum against waste]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 10 June 2010, p. 2. She lost her seat in Cabinet in a subsequent reshuffle, but was retained as a special advisor to the Prime Minister. In the [[Japanese House of Councillors election, 2010|2010 House of Councillors election]], she garnered a record 1,710,734 constituency votes.{{cite web|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/election/sangiin/2010/profile/ye13004.htm |title=蓮 舫 : プロフィル : 参院選2010 : 参院選 : 選挙 : YOMIURI ONLINE（読売新聞） |publisher=Yomiuri.co.jp |date= |accessdate=2016-09-15}} She also served as a member of the [[Cabinet of Japan]] from 2010 to 2012, serving as Minister for Government Revitalisation and [[Minister of State for Consumer Affairs and Food Safety]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}} In September 2011, she was re-appointed as State Minister of Government Revitalization (responsible for administrative reforms) in the cabinet of then prime minister [[Yoshihiko Noda]]. Her new portfolio also included responsibility for civil service reform, gender equality and Japan's declining birthrate. She served in this post until a cabinet reshuffle in January 2012. The DPJ was ousted from government in the [[Japanese general election, 2012|2012 general election]], following which Renhō returned to the opposition bench. She retained her seat in the [[Japanese House of Councillors election, 2016|2016 House of Councillors Election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/07/10/national/politics-diplomacy/dps-renho-wins-third-upper-house-term/#.V465srgrJeV |title=DP's Renho wins third Upper House term |publisher=The Japan Times |date=2016-07-10 |accessdate=2016-09-15}} === Head of the Democratic Party (2016-17) === In [[Democratic Party (Japan, 2016) leadership election, 2016|September 2016, she was elected as the leader of Japan's Democratic Party]], making her the first woman elected as their leader and the first person with mixed ethnic heritage and dual-citizenship to head a major political party in Japan.{{cite web |title=Japan’s Democratic Party Elects Renho as New Leader |date=September 15, 2016 |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-democratic-party-elects-renho-as-new-leader-1473918605}}{{cite web|url=http://qz.com/782214/japans-opposition-party-just-elected-renho-murata-to-be-its-leader-the-first-time-a-woman-will-fill-the-role/ |title=Japan’s opposition party just elected Renho Murata to be its leader—the first time a woman will fill the role — Quartz |publisher=Qz.com |date=2016 |accessdate=2016-09-15}} Upon her election as president of the Democratic Party, ''[[The Japan Times]]'' reported on several of her policies. They reported that she is opposed to revisions of [[Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution|Article 9 of the Constitution]], but is willing to join debates with the [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic Party]] on other constitutional revisions. They also reported that she views [[Abenomics]] to be a partial success, but pushes for greater investment in education, child-rearing and nursing care. She has also ruled out forming a coalition government with the [[Japanese Communist Party]] and opposes the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]].[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/09/15/national/politics-diplomacy/renho-elected-leader-of-main-opposition-democratic-party/ "Renhō elected leader of main opposition Democratic Party"]. ''[[The Japan Times]]''. Published 15 September 2016.
Retrieved 28 December 2016. During the presidential election, Renhō claimed that she had given up her Taiwanese citizenship. However, reports emerged that her Taiwanese citizenship had not been properly renounced. In response to doubts regarding her legal status, she took steps to renounce her Taiwanese citizenship beginning in late 2016. In July 2017, the Democratic Party suffered a very poor showing in the [[Tokyo prefectural election, 2017|Tokyo prefectural election]]. Some senior party members blamed the results, in part, on the ongoing questions surrounding Renhō's citizenship.{{Cite news|url=https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170719/p2a/00m/0na/021000c|title=Renho's nationality disclosure raises discrimination concerns, fails to unite DP|date=2017-07-19|work=Mainichi Daily News|access-date=2017-10-10|language=en}} In response to these concerns, she provided evidence of her renunciation of Taiwanese citizenship at a press conference later that month. Days after her press conference, and days following the resignation of former prime minister [[Yoshihiko Noda]] as party secretary-general, Renhō resigned as head of the party, stating that she had not shown sufficient ability to lead it.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-27/japan-s-main-opposition-leader-resigns-amid-turmoil-in-her-party|title=Japan's Main Opposition Leader Resigns Amid Turmoil in Her Party|date=2017-07-27|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-10-10}}{{cite|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/japan-opposition-leader-renho-steps-down/news-story/820fb972025906d96374f68a9df289dc|title=Japan opposition leader Renho steps down|date= 27 July 2017|accessdate=27 July 2017}} === In the CDP (2017-) === Dissatisfied with the ambiguous direction of the DP leadership post the [[Japanese general election, 2017|2017 election]], Renho expressed interest in joining the new progressive [[Constitutional Democratic Party of Japan|Constitutional Democratic Party]] and had an exploratory talk with CDP leader [[Yukio Edano]] in mid-December.{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/12/15/national/politics-diplomacy/frustrated-ex-dp-chief-renho-wants-know-kind-party-cdp|title=Frustrated ex-DP chief Renho wants to know ‘what kind of party’ CDP is|author=[[Jiji Press]] via [[Japan Times]]|date=2017-12-15|access-date=2017-12-29|language=en}} She applied to join the CDP on December 26, 2017 citing the DP's lack of policy directions and the CDP's conversely clear policy directions.{{Cite news|url=https://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20171226-00000050-jij-pol|title=蓮舫元代表も立憲入りへ＝民進、混迷深まる|author=[[Jiji Press]] via [[Yahoo! Japan]]|date=2017-12-26|access-date=2017-12-29|language=Japanese}}{{Cite news|url=https://this.kiji.is/318319999968674913|title=蓮舫氏、立民へ入党届|author=[[Kyodo News]]|date=2017-12-26|access-date=2017-12-29|language=Japanese}} The CDP admitted her into the party on December 28, 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/12/28/national/politics-diplomacy/cdp-grants-membership-former-dp-leader-renho|title=DP grants membership to former DP leader Renho|author=[[Jiji Press]] via [[Japan Times]]|date=2017-12-28|access-date=2017-12-29|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.sankei.com/smp/politics/news/180110/plt1801100020-s1.html|title=蓮舫氏が脱「二重党籍」　民進党が離党届受理|author=[[Sankei Shimbun]]|date=2018-01-10|access-date=2018-01-10|language=Japanese}} == Family == Her husband, {{nihongo4|Nobuyuki Murata|村田 信之|Murata Nobuyuki}}, is a journalist and a guest lecturer at several universities. In 1997, she gave birth to twins. She has two siblings, one brother who is one year older, and one brother who is two years younger.{{cite news|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20100502x1.html|title=Japan's fiscal firebrand|date=2 June 2010|work=[[Japan Times]]|accessdate=8 June 2010}} [[Mark Chen]], a Taiwanese politician and former Secretary-General of the [[Office of the President of the Republic of China]], is a distant relative of hers.{{cite news|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/world/news/20100608-OYT1T00957.htm?from=top|script-title=ja:「バナナ娘」蓮舫が大臣に…台湾で大々的報道 |date=8 June 2010|work=[[Yomiuri Shimbun]]|accessdate=8 June 2010|language=ja}} She lives in Tokyo with her husband, children, and mother. == References == [[File:Renho.JPG|thumb|Renhō in 2008]] {{Reflist|33em}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.renho.jp/}} * [http://www.dpj.or.jp/english/member/?detail_121=1 Renhō profile at DPJ site] {{s-start}} {{s-par|jp-upr}} {{s-bef|before=[[Toshio Ogawa]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file= Pala di santa cristina al tiverone.jpg | title= Santa Cristina al Tiverone Altarpiece | artist=Lorenzo Lotto | year=c. 1504–1506 | medium=Oil on panel | height_metric=267 | width_metric=179 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= Quinto di Treviso | museum=Church of Santa Cristina }} '''''Santa Cristina al Tiverone Altarpiece''''' is a painting by the Italian Renaissance painter [[Lorenzo Lotto]], executed around 1504-1506. It is still housed in its original location, the parish church of Santa Cristina in Quinto di Treviso, a ''[[frazione]]'' of [[Treviso]], northern [[Italy]].
Measuring 90x179 cm ([[lunette]]) and 177x162 cm (central panel), it is signed "Laurentius / Lotus / P.[inxit]" at the base of the throne. It was perhaps commissioned around 1505 by bishop [[Bernardo de' Rossi]], in whose court Lotto worked at the time. It was released on 14 May 1507, just before the artists' move to [[Recanati]].
==Description== The main panel, of rectangular shape, shows a [[sacred conversation]] with ''Madonna and Child'' sitting on a large throne. Around her are the saints Peter, Christine, Liberalis and Jerome, all enclosed within a classical style architecture.
The composition derives from [[Giovanni Bellini]]'s [[San Zaccaria Altarpiece]], as testified by the niche in the throne with Byzantine mosaics, and the oriental carpet at Mary's feet. Perhaps inspired by [[Giorgione]]'s ''[[Castelfranco Madonna]]'' is the figure of Liberalis, the patron saint of Treviso, as a knight holding a model of the city in a hand.
The baby Jesus holds a [[Carduelis|goldfinch]], an allegory of his future Passion. The right side opens on an external wall covered by grass.
The lunette shows instead a ''[[Pietà]]'', also based on Bellini, with the dead Christ supported by two angels.
==Sources== *{{cite book|first=Carlo|last=Pirovano|title=Lotto|publisher=Electa|location=Milan|year= 2002}}
==External links== *[http://www.polomuseale.firenze.it/catalogo/scheda.asp?nctn=00099612&value=1 Page at the museum website]

'''Serial imagery''' is the repeating of one image in many variations or forms. It is a central idea in modern and contemporary art. It can take several forms. A portrait can painted in differing hues and backgrounds with subtle changes to the subject as in Van Gogh's L'Arlésienne and Claude Monet’s [[Rouen Cathedral (Monet)|Rouen Cathedral]] Another type is where the same subject is painted at different times of day or seasons of the year for example [[Claude Monet]] in his [[Poplar Series (Monet)|Poplars]], [[Haystacks (Monet)|Haystacks]]. The same subject may also be rendered in different mediums, and in different poses, thus, the practice of underpainting may be considered a form of serial imagery even if the image is lost in the completed work. It is common in photography where multiple exposures at varies angles are taken with different lenses etc. in search of the desired effect. It is also used in literature, especially poetry.
Some say the [[Impressionists]] and their contemporaries were the first to use it, but this is not the case. It was used by [[Francisco Goya]] with his La maja desnuda and La maja vestida (1797-1800). It is seen in classical art whenever studies were made and used to produce a finished work. This was a common practice for [[Leonardo da Vinci]]', Michelangelo and most of the other classical artists although most of their studies and sketches did not survive.
Here is an example from literature.
What Say You? (By Eric Ericson)
What say you faithful tree? In summer’s glory standing tall while autumn’s minions sneak to steal your green, so you go necked into winter.
What say you faithful tree? In golden robes resplendent, your arm’s reach skyward showing off your finery, knowing this to shall pass.
What say you faithful tree standing necked in the snow? I would pity you, as winter’s icy breath bites your fingers and tears your flesh, but you don’t want me to.
What say you faithful tree? As the sun turns warm all clad in white blossoms with velvet leaves just beginning to show. What say you?
(copyright by author. used with permission, This poem may be copied if authorship is included and used for educational purposes only)
[[John Coplans]] supplied a critical approach in an exhibition at the Pasadena Art Museum in 1968.
==Literature== • John Coplans: ''Serial Imagery'', exh. cat. Pasadena Art Museum 1968, New York Graphic Society, 1968 • Eric Ericson: “To Everything a Season”, What Say You? page 33 published 2010

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[Sir]] |name = Seymour Hicks |image = Hicks.title.jpg |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1871|1|30}} |birth_place = [[Saint Helier|St. Hélier]], [[Jersey]], Channel Islands |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1949|4|6|1871|1|30}} |death_place = [[Hampshire]], England |occupation = Actor |spouse = [[Ellaline Terriss]] (1893–1949) (his death) }}
'''Sir Edward Seymour Hicks''' (30 January 1871 – 6 April 1949), better known as '''Seymour Hicks''', was a British actor, [[music hall]] performer, playwright, screenwriter, [[actor-manager]] and producer. He became known, early in his career, for writing, starring in and producing [[Edwardian musical comedy]], often together with his famous wife, [[Ellaline Terriss]]. His most famous acting role was that of [[Ebenezer Scrooge]] in [[Charles Dickens]]'s ''[[A Christmas Carol]]''.
Making his stage début at the age of nine and performing professionally by sixteen, Hicks joined a theatrical company and toured America before starring in ''Under the Clock'' in 1893, the first musical [[revue]] ever staged in London. Following this, he starred in a revival of ''[[Little Jack Sheppard]]'' at the [[Gaiety Theatre, London]] which brought him to the attention of impresario [[George Edwardes]]. Edwardes cast Hicks in his next show, ''[[The Shop Girl]]'', in 1894. Its success led to his participation in two more of Edwardes's hit "girl" musicals, ''[[The Circus Girl]]'' (1896) and ''[[A Runaway Girl]]'' (1898), both starring Terriss. He first played the role of Ebenezer Scrooge in 1901 and eventually played it thousands of times onstage. Hicks, along with his wife, joined the producer [[Charles Frohman]] in his theatre company and wrote and starred in a series of extraordinarily successful musicals, including ''[[Bluebell in Fairyland]]'' (1901), ''[[Quality Street (play)|Quality Street]]'' (1902), ''[[The Earl and the Girl]]'' (1903) and ''[[The Catch of the Season]]'' (1904).
Hicks used his fortune from these shows to commission the building of the [[Aldwych Theatre]] in 1905 and the [[Gielgud Theatre|Hicks Theatre]] in 1906, opening the latter with a new hit show, ''[[The Beauty of Bath]]''. His stage performances were less successful in later years, and he opted instead to star in music hall tours, including ''Pebbles on the Beach'' (1912). He continued to write light comedies, the most popular of which was ''[[The Happy Day]]'' (1916). On film, he first appeared in ''[[Scrooge (1913 film)|Scrooge]]'' and ''[[David Garrick (1913 film)|David Garrick]]'' both from 1913. Later notable films included ''[[The Lambeth Walk (film)|The Lambeth Walk]]'' (1939) and ''[[Busman's Honeymoon (film)|Busman's Honeymoon]]'' (1940), and his last film was in the year of his death, 1949.
==Life and career== Hicks was born in [[Saint Helier|St. Hélier]] on the island of [[Jersey]]. At the age of nine, he appeared as Little Buttercup in [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]'s ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'' at his school in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]. After that, he was determined to be an actor.
===Early career=== [[File:1917c.jpg|thumb|upright|Hicks in "A Court Scandal", 1899]] Hicks first appeared professionally on stage at the age of sixteen in a production of ''In the Ranks'' at the Grand, Islington. In 1889, he joined the theatrical company of [[William Hunter Kendal|Mr.]] and [[Madge Kendal|Mrs. Kendal]] for an American tour where they presented a repertory of contemporary plays. Hicks starred as Dr. Watson in the first revue show ever staged in London, ''Under the Clock'' (1893), a parody of [[Sherlock Holmes]] and Watson written by Hicks with [[Charles Brookfield]] (who played Holmes), at the Royal Court Theatre.<ref>[http://special.lib.umn.edu/rare/ush/10E1.html Special Collections: K Plays], University of Minnesota, 8 April 2005, accessed 18 November 2009</ref> That same year, he married [[Ellaline Terriss]].<ref name=TerrissDNB>Taylor, C.M.P. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/printable/40483 Terriss, Ellaline. ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography''], Oxford University Press, accessed 7 January 2012</ref> After that, he starred in a revival of ''[[Little Jack Sheppard]]'' at the [[Gaiety Theatre, London]]. This brought him to the attention of the impresario [[George Edwardes]]. In 1894, Hicks joined his wife in the successful "Fairy [[pantomime]]", ''[[Cinderella]]'', produced by [[Henry Irving]] with music by Oscar Barrett, where she had been playing the title role. He played Thisbe, one of Cinderella's half-sisters who, in this version, were "[[Girton College]] girls who can jabber Greek and Latin, read French, play golf, and indulge in manly exercises. Thisbe has an affectation for intellectuality – Ibsen, Spooks, and the new humor."
Edwardes gave Hicks the chance to star in his next show, ''[[The Shop Girl]]'' (1894), which became a hit at the Gaiety in 1894, playing for 546 performances. Hicks's wife joined Edwardes's company during the run of the show, replacing the star in the title role, and together they made the musical an even bigger hit. The following year, Hicks transferred with the show to [[Broadway theater|Broadway]] for a short run<ref>{{cite book|last=Green| first=Stanley| title=Encyclopedia of the Musical Theatre|year=1991|publisher=Da Capo Press|location=Cambridge, Mass.|isbn=978-0-306-80113-6|pages=378|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZWIRAljCR7oC&pg=PA378}}</ref> and then toured in America in 1895 with his wife, where they befriended the American novelist [[Richard Harding Davis]]. At the instance of [[W. S. Gilbert]], Hicks wrote a drama called ''One of the Best'', a vehicle for his father-in-law [[William Terriss]] at the [[Adelphi Theatre]], based on the famous [[Dreyfus Trial]]. The Hickses were frequent guests of Gilbert at his estate in [[Grim's Dyke]]. Hicks hurried back from America for the opening in December 1895. It ran for over a year.<ref>Stedman, pp. 307–08</ref>
Another early success for the young couple was ''[[The Circus Girl]]'' (1896). Hicks and Terriss both had a comedy background, and they transformed the "lovers" roles in the new genre of Edwardian musicals from overly sentimental to mischievous and light-hearted characters exchanging witty banter. Hicks then worked as co-author on ''[[The Yashmak]]'' and then on one of the Gaiety Theatre's most successful shows, ''[[A Runaway Girl]]'' (1898), in which Terriss played the title role. This was followed by ''With Flying Colours'' (1899). Also in 1899, Hicks starred as the Duc De Richelieu in ''A Court Scandal'', a comedy adapted by Aubrey Boucicault and Osmond Shillingford from ''Les Premières Armes de Richelieu'' by [[Dumanoir]], at the Court Theatre.<ref>[http://www.lafayette.150m.com/hic1918.html ''A Court Scandal''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080210183354/http://lafayette.150m.com/hic1918.html |date=10 February 2008 }}</ref> The same year, he and Terriss adopted a daughter, Mabel, and Terriss gave birth to their second child, Elizabeth ("Betty), in 1904.<ref name=TerrissDNB/>
===Frohman years=== [[File:Cover of the Vocal Score of Seymour Hicks' The Earl and the Girl.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Cover of Vocal Score]] In early 1900, the Hickses played in their only Broadway show together, ''My Daughter-in-law'', at the Frohman brothers' [[Lyceum Theatre (New York, 1885–1902)|old Lyceum Theatre]].<ref>[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=5154 ''My Daughter-in-law''], IBDB, accessed 11 April 2012</ref> They then joined forces with producer [[Charles Frohman]] and, in his company, over a period of seven years, they played the leads in a series of musicals written by Hicks, including ''[[Bluebell in Fairyland]]'' (1901 with music by [[Walter Slaughter]] and lyrics by [[Charles H. Taylor (lyricist)|Charles Taylor]] – this Christmas show for children was continually revived for the next four decades) and ''[[The Cherry Girl]]'' (1902). Hicks and Terriss also starred in ''[[Quality Street (play)|Quality Street]]'' in 1902. At that time, they moved to a new home, The Old Forge, at Merstham, Surrey. Their cul-de-sac was renamed "Quality Street".
Hicks also wrote the highly successful ''[[The Earl and the Girl]]'' (1903) and the successful ''[[The Catch of the Season]]'' (1904 with [[Herbert Haines]] and Taylor). Ellaline was pregnant with Betty, and so [[Zena Dare]] originated the leading role in ''The Catch of the Season'' until Terriss could assume the role. Hicks wrote, and Frohman produced, ''The Talk of the Town'' (1905 with Haines and Taylor),<ref>Moss, Simon. [http://www.c20th.com/GSarchiveother.htm Programme and description of ''The Talk of the Town'',] ''Gilbert & Sullivan, a selling exhibition of memorabilia, Archive: Other items''</ref> ''[[The Beauty of Bath]]'' (1906 with Haines and Taylor; the show included additional lyrics by newcomer [[P. G. Wodehouse]] and additional music by [[Jerome Kern]]), ''My Darling'' (1907 with Haines),<ref>[http://www.guidetomusicaltheatre.com/shows_m/MyDarling.html ''My Darling''], the Guide to Musical Theatre, accessed 25 February 2010</ref> and ''[[The Gay Gordons (musical)|The Gay Gordons]]'' (1907). Hicks used some of the fortune he received from these shows to build the [[Aldwych Theatre]] in 1905 and the [[Gielgud Theatre|Hicks Theatre]] in 1906, which was renamed the "Globe Theatre" in 1909 and then the "Gielgud Theatre" in 1994. ''The Beauty of Bath'' was the first production at the theatre.
===Later stage work=== [[File:Hicks1.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Drawing of Hicks in ''[[Quality Street (play)|Quality Street]]'']] In ''The Dashing Little Duke'' (1909; with [[C. Hayden Coffin]], [[Courtice Pounds]] and [[Louie Pounds]]), produced by Hicks at the Hicks Theatre, which was less successful, Hicks' wife played the title role (a woman playing a man).<ref>Johnson, Colin. [http://www.gsarchive.net/british/dashing/index.html Information about, and MIDI files for, ''The Dashing Little Duke''], 2003, The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive, accessed 31 March 2018</ref> When she missed several performances due to illness, Hicks played the role – possibly the only case in the history of a musical where a husband succeeded to his wife's role. The piece was based on ''A Court Scandal'', in which Hicks had played in 1899. Hicks then wrote and starred in ''Captain Kidd'' (1910), an adaptation with music and lyrics by [[Leslie Stuart]] and [[Adrian Ross]], of the American farce ''The Dictator'' (1904 by [[Richard Harding Davis]]).<ref>Lamb, p. 206</ref> This flopped, bringing an end to the era of supremacy in London's musical theatre of Hicks and Terriss.<ref>[http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/british/authors/hicks.html Seymour Hicks], British Musical Theatre, 31 August 2004 Gilbert and Sullivan Archive, accessed 2 February 2012</ref> Hicks appeared in his first [[Shakespeare]] play that year, ''Richard III''. The same year, he penned the first of several autobiographies. The following year, he took a company on a tour of South Africa. After the outbreak of [[World War I]], Hicks was the first British actor to bring a tour to France (with Terriss), giving concerts to British troops at the front. Because of this, he was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre 1914–1918 (France)|French Croix de Guerre]]. Hicks was briefly declared bankrupt in 1915.<ref>"Mr. Seymour Hicks", ''Western Times'', 3 December 1915, p. 10</ref><ref>"Mr Seymour Hicks and his Creditors", ''The Glasgow Herald'', 19 October 1915, p. 9</ref>
Hicks and Terriss concentrated on comedy roles and music hall tours in later years, including ''Pebbles on the Beach'' (1912), singing and dancing 'Alexander's Ragtime Band'. Their one return to musical comedy, ''Cash on Delivery'' (1917), confirmed the public's preference for comedy revues and music hall. Hicks continued to write light, escapist comedies, such as ''[[The Happy Day]]'' (1916), ''Sleeping Partners'' (1917) and, after the war, satiric farces, such as ''Good Luck'' and ''Head Over Heels'' (1923) and adaptations of French farces (''The Man in Dress Clothes'').
===Film career, Scrooge and later years=== {{further information| Seymour Hicks filmography}}
[[File:Mr&Mrs Semour Hicks.jpg|thumb|upright|Hicks with Terriss and their daughter Betty]] Hicks appeared in three early silent films: ''[[Scrooge (1913 film)|Scrooge]]'' and ''[[David Garrick (1913 film)|David Garrick]]'' in 1913, and ''A Prehistoric Love Story'' in 1915.<ref name=BFI>[http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/individual/11959?view=credit "Hicks, Seymour"], British Film Institute, accessed 1 April 2012</ref> He decided in 1923 to produce his own films. His first film, in which he starred, was ''[[Always Tell Your Wife]]'', which was based on one of his plays. While making that film, Hicks fired the director and hired an unknown young director to make his debut: [[Alfred Hitchcock]].<ref>[http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/52225 ''Always Tell Your Wife''], British Film Institute, accessed 1 April 2012</ref> Hicks directed ''Sleeping Partners'' (1930) and ''[[Glamour (1931 film)|Glamour]]'' (1931). In addition, over a dozen films were made either from his plays or his scripts, and he starred in about twenty films, many with his wife. One of his early films was ''[[Money for Nothing (1932 film)|Money for Nothing]]'' (1932)<ref name=BFI/>
In 1931, he was awarded the [[Legion d'honneur|Legion of Honour]] for his promotion of French drama on the English stage. In 1934, he had taken over [[Daly's Theatre]] in London, where he produced and appeared in a series of successful plays including ''Vintage Wine'' that he and [[Ashley Dukes]] adapted from a novel.
Hicks's most famous role was that of [[Ebenezer Scrooge]] in [[Charles Dickens]]'s ''[[A Christmas Carol]]''. He first played this role in 1901 and eventually played it thousands of times onstage, often at benefits, and twice on film: the 1913 [[silent film]] ''[[Scrooge (1913 film)|Scrooge]]'' and the 1935 film ''[[Scrooge (1935 film)|Scrooge]]'', produced in England. In 1926, [[Pathé Pictures]] released the 1913 film in America under the title ''Old Scrooge''. This 1926 print has been released on DVD. The 1935 ''Scrooge'' was the first feature-length film version of the story with sound. The film has been praised for its vivid atmosphere, but most of the ghosts in the film are not seen on screen, except for the [[Ghost of Christmas Present]] ([[Oscar Asche]]). [[Donald Calthrop]] portrays Bob Cratchit, and [[Maurice Evans (actor)|Maurice Evans]] has a bit part as one of Scrooge's debtors. Most prints in circulation are of the abridged, six-reel (hour-long) version. The film was seldom seen due to the popularity of the 1938 and the 1951 film versions of Dickens's novel. Poor-quality prints were shown on television in the 1980s, but in 2002 the film was restored to its original eight-reel length and issued on DVD. In 2007 the hour-long version was issued in a colourised edition.
Among his other film appearances, Hicks starred in the film version of his show ''[[Vintage Wine]]'' (1935) and as Sir John Tremayne in ''[[The Lambeth Walk (film)|The Lambeth Walk]]'' (1939), the film version of the stage musical ''[[Me and My Girl]]'', ''[[Young Man's Fancy (film)|Young Man's Fancy]]'' (1939), ''[[Pastor Hall]]'' (1940) and ''[[Busman's Honeymoon (film)|Busman's Honeymoon]]'' (1940).<ref name=BFI/> Hicks wrote for films until 1941 (''Kisses for Breakfast'', in which he starred, based on the French play ''The Matrimonial Bed'' by [[André Mouëzy-Éon]] and [[Yves Mirande]]). When World War II began, he acted, on 12 November 1939, as the master of ceremonies at the first concert given in France by the newly formed ENSA (Entertainment National Service Association). For this action, Hicks was awarded his second Croix de Guerre.
Hicks was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in 1934. Later films included ''[[Fame is the Spur (film)|Fame is the Spur]]'' (1947) and ''[[Silent Dust]]'' (1949).<ref name=BFI/> He continued appearing on stage and in films until a year before his death in [[Hampshire]], England, at the age of 78.

Hartnoll (ed.), ''The Oxford Companion to the Theatre'', 4th ed. (London, 1983) * {{cite book|last=Stedman|first=Jane W.|year=1996|title=W. S. {{Infobox Artwork | image_file = Paul Delvaux The Great Sirens.png | title = The Great Sirens | artist = [[Paul Delvaux]] | year = 1947 | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on masonite]] | height_metric = 201.9 | width_metric = 309.9 | height_imperial = 79{{frac|1|2}} | width_imperial = 122 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[New York City]] | museum = [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] | accession = 1979.356 }}
'''''The Great Sirens''''' ({{Lang-fr|'''Les grandes sirènes'''}}) is a large 1947 painting by the Belgian painter [[Paul Delvaux]] in the collection of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].<ref name="met">{{Cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/481994|title=The Great Sirens|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|accessdate=2017-03-14}}</ref>
The picture depicts a group of partially nude women in moonlight, sitting motionless before a hill bearing two Greco-Roman style buildings. According to the description from the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], the setting "reveals the painter's admiration of the work of [[Giorgio de Chirico]]". The women in the foreground are unashamedly, if not threateningly, seductive and in the distance mermaids are working their magic on a lone individual in a bowler hat. The whole composition evokes fantasies of erotic love.<ref name="met"/>
The work is currently (2018) not on view.
==Provenance== The painting was first exhibited at the Galerie René Drouin in Paris on 5 March 1948. It was bought by the dramatist Claude Spaak in 1949, after which it was sold several times to different collectors in Brussels. The American music producer [[Jean Aberbach]] bought it in 1967. He then traded it with his brother [[Julian Aberbach]], who wanted this painting and works by [[René Magritte]] in exchange for some sculptures by [[Alberto Giacometti]].<ref>{{Cite book|last=Biszick-Lockwood|first=Bar|year=2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uAwGCtXPvMgC&pg=PA282|title=Restless Giant: The Life and Times of Jean Aberbach and Hill and Range Songs|location=[[Urbana, Illinois]]|publisher=[[University of Illinois Press]]|p=282|isbn=978-0-252-03507-4}}</ref> Julian Aberbach gave ''The Great Sirens'' to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in 1979.<ref name="met" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/481994 ''The Great Sirens''] at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]
